awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Enhancing Impact of Broadening Participation in Computing Efforts through the STARS Cohort Conference Attendance Program
awd_abstract_narration:
Temple University, in collaboration with North Carolina State University, will use their team's experience with the Students and Technology in Academics, Research, and Service (STARS) Computing Alliance to create a new activity - the STARS Cohort Conference Attendance Program. The effort will develop, test, and evaluate a model that faculty can use to support cohorts of students attending computer science (CS) conferences. The STARS cohort model has been shown to increase students' sense of belonging, identity as computing professionals, engagement, and academic outcomes, with disproportionately positive benefits for students from underrepresented groups in computing.  This project will extend that model, engaging and training members of the Computer and Information Sciences and Engineering (CISE) Directorate's Principal Investigators (PIs) in building community among students attending conferences. 

The STARS Cohort Conference Attendance Program will support the development of the model, a pilot workshop to disseminate that model, provide scholarships for 20 PIs to attend a STARS Cohorts training workshop, supply 100 scholarships for undergraduate,  graduate students, and faculty (particularly those from Minority Serving Institutions) to attend either the Richard Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing or the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing in 5-person cohorts. Thus, the STARS Cohort program will provide a low barrier to entry for new PIs wishing to engage in meaningful BPC efforts, in the hopes that the experience will serve as a hook to engage the new-to-BPC PIs in post-conference BPC cohort activities at their home institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Academic computing departments continue to seek ways to broaden participation of historically excluded groups in computing. In recent years, many departments have encouraged individual faculty, staff, and students to attend diversity-oriented conferences, like the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing and the Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing. Such conferences present opportunities to engage in professional development, develop academic and professional networks, be inspired by leaders in computing, and celebrate diversity in computing. This project supported a pilot launch of STARS IGNITE, a program designed to amplify the impact of attending diversity-focused conferences for both individuals and computing departments by supporting cohort-based conference attendance that focuses on taking action to broaden participation in computing.   

Offered by the STARS Computing Corps Alliance for Broadening Participation in Computing, the STARS Ignite program guides departmental cohorts of faculty, staff, and students to attend a diversity-focused computing conference and to use their experiences to develop a plan for broadening participation in computing (BPC) at their home institutions. Faculty apply to participate in the STARS Ignite program as STARS Ignite cohort leaders. Ignite Cohort Leaders attend monthly STARS Ignite webinars, which provide them with information and guidance on identifying challenges to broadening participation in computing at their home institutions, identifying evidence-based approaches and resources available to address those challenges, and working with their cohorts to create a BPC plan that includes student-focused efforts that address the BPC context. Cohort Leaders leverage STARS Ignite template materials to recruit students to participate in their departmental cohort, using strategies that align with their departmental goals for student cohort participation. The STARS IGNITE program includes pre-conference cohort development activities to build community, identity, and sense of belonging among students. Cohorts are provided with travel scholarships to attend a diversity-focused conference (e.g., Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing, Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing), and commit to creating a plan to ignite BPC efforts within their own computing departments. By attending diversity-focused conferences as a STARS Ignite cohort that is prepared to think about context, needs, and action for broadening participation in computing, the impact of conference attendance can be amplified for individual students and for their home computing departments. Following the conference, the STARS IGNITE program includes faculty cohort leaders in webinars that focus on further development and implementation of their cohort’s BPC plan, and shares information about evaluating BPC efforts.  

The STARS Ignite program provided conference registrations and stipends to support cohort members to participate in the Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing and the co-located STARS Celebration, which included sessions that were specific to designing, implementing, and evaluating student-led efforts for broadening participation in computing, in 2019, 2020, and 2021. Through workshops, webinars, and online resources, the STARS Ignite program has prepared and faculty from guided cohorts of faculty and students from 19 universities to follow up on what they have learned at a diversity-focused conference and to design and implement plans to broaden participation of underrepresented groups in computing in their home computing department. The project has supported over 250 students and faculty to develop knowledge about data-driven and evidence-based approaches to broadening participation of historically excluded and marginalized groups in computing, and to enhance the impact of their attendance at diversity-focused computing conferences.

 


Last Modified: 01/26/2022
Modified by: Jamie Payton
